channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Researchers working on Covid-19 treatments urged to be thorough
item.description: Top scientists are urging researchers who are rushing to develop Covid-19 treatments to ensure they rigorously test drugs.

item.title: Petitioner urges police to talanoa after Armed Response Teams scrapped
item.description: The woman who launched a petition urging police to scrap their Armed Response Team (ART) believes it put her job in jeopardy, but it was worth it now the squad has been axed for good.

item.title: Police admit to failings in arrest of young Māori boy
item.description: Police have apologised to the whānau of a 16-year-old boy from Masterton who was arrested last year after being mistaken for a suspect.

item.title: Antarctica NZ limits activity in continent to stay Covid-19 free
item.description: Antarctica New Zealand is cracking down on unnecessary travel to the continent in a bid to keep Covid-19 out.

item.title: School handles Black Lives Matter poster removal internally
item.description: The outcome of an investigation at a private Christchurch school, where posters promoting the Black Lives Matter movement were torn down, is to remain confidential.

item.title: Christchurch's historic Isaac Theatre Royal restarts operations
item.description: Christchurch's historic Isaac Theatre Royal is gradually restarting operations after being shut due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Nearly all of Jucy rentals stolen during lockdown recovered
item.description: Almost all of the Jucy rental vehicles stolen from a car yard in South Auckland during the level 4 lockdown have been tracked down.

item.title: Police ending Armed Response Teams after trial - Commissioner
item.description: Police Commissioner Andrew Coster has today announced that Armed Response Teams will not be part of the New Zealand policing model in the future.

item.title: Covid Tracing app Bluetooth tech unreliable - NZDF
item.description: The Defence Force has told the government that Bluetooth contact tracing technology may result in "false contacts" or fail to record contact.

item.title: Minister warns immigrants labour market gaps may close
item.description: The government is looking at how up to 10,000 immigrants can return to New Zealand, Minister Iain Lees-Galloway says, but they may need to reconsider their employment.

item.title: Te Anau murder accused revealed as victim's husband
item.description: The man accused of murdering Balclutha woman Shirley Reedy in Te Anau last month can now be revealed as her husband, Rodney Fallowfield.

item.title: Wellington Airport expansion plans delayed
item.description: A massive drop in passenger numbers has forced Wellington Airport to delay plans for a billion-dollar-plus expansion and upgrade.

item.title: Police name man who died in Hamilton homicide inquiry
item.description: Police have named the man whose death in Hamilton last week sparked a homicide inquiry.

item.title: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern reveals move to level 1 from midnight
item.description: PM Jacinda Ardern has revealed New Zealand will move to its lowest restrictions - alert level 1 - at midnight tonight.

item.title: Ruakura Port project closer to reality with more than $30m in funding
item.description: The Ruakura Port development north of Hamilton has recieved more than $30 million from the Provincial Growth Fund and the commercial arm of iwi powerhouse Waikato-Tainui.

item.title: Charges laid over vineyard on Wairau Bar archaeological site
item.description: Two people have been charged in relation to a vineyard built at Wairau Bar in Blenheim, where one of the earliest Māori settlements is thought to have been.

item.title: Hapū, residents weigh legal action over Opua development
item.description: Hapū and locals of a small Bay of Islands town have vowed to fight a plan to build 17 houses on land they want protected for a public park.

item.title: Māori mothers describe child welfare system as dangerous and brutal in new report
item.description: Māori mothers of newborns involved with Oranga Tamariki say the child welfare system is dangerous, brutal and racist.
